rev.comment: This image use does not comply with [[WP:NFCC]] #10c and MUST be removed until it does. Thank you.
rev.diff:
Line 58: Line 58:
===Incidents===
===Incidents===
On January 15, 1953, [[PRR 4876]] headed up Train 173, the ''[[Federal Express (passenger train)|Federal]]'', from [[Boston]], [[Massachusetts]] to Washington, D.C. The train passed a [[railway signal|signal]] {{convert|2.1|mi}} north of [[Union Station (Washington, D.C.)|Union Station]] traveling between {{convert|60|and|70|mph|km/h}} and the engineer decreased the throttle and started applying the brakes in preparation for entering the station.<ref>"Accident at Union Station", p. 6.</ref> When the engineer realized that the train was not slowing down, and applying the [[emergency brake (train)|emergency brake]] had no effect, he proceeded to sound the engine's horn. A [[signalman (rail)|signalman]], on hearing the horn and noting the excessive speed of the 4876, phoned ahead to the [[station master]]'s office.<ref name="Loftus 16">Loftus 1953, p. 16.</ref> 4876 negotiated several [[Railroad switch|switches]] without derailing, at speeds well over the safe speed limits and entered the station at around {{convert|35|to|40|mph}}.<ref name="accident 5">"Accident at Union Station", p. 5.</ref> The train rammed the [[buffer stop]]s, continued through the station master's office and into the [[concourse]].<ref name="accident 5"/> The weight of 4876 caused it to fall through the floor and into the station's basement. A temporary floor was erected over the engine, and the hole it created, for the [[United States presidential inauguration|inauguration]] of [[President of the United States|President]] [[Dwight D. Eisenhower]].<ref name="Loftus 16"/> 4876 was eventually dismantled and removed from the basement. It was reassembled in Altoona, before being put back into service.
On January 15, 1953, [[PRR 4876]] headed up Train 173, the ''[[Federal Express (passenger train)|Federal]]'', from [[Boston]], [[Massachusetts]] to Washington, D.C. The train passed a [[railway signal|signal]] {{convert|2.1|mi}} north of [[Union Station (Washington, D.C.)|Union Station]] traveling between {{convert|60|and|70|mph|km/h}} and the engineer decreased the throttle and started applying the brakes in preparation for entering the station.<ref>"Accident at Union Station", p. 6.</ref> When the engineer realized that the train was not slowing down, and applying the [[emergency brake (train)|emergency brake]] had no effect, he proceeded to sound the engine's horn. A [[signalman (rail)|signalman]], on hearing the horn and noting the excessive speed of the 4876, phoned ahead to the [[station master]]'s office.<ref name="Loftus 16">Loftus 1953, p. 16.</ref> 4876 negotiated several [[Railroad switch|switches]] without derailing, at speeds well over the safe speed limits and entered the station at around {{convert|35|to|40|mph}}.<ref name="accident 5">"Accident at Union Station", p. 5.</ref> The train rammed the [[buffer stop]]s, continued through the station master's office and into the [[concourse]].<ref name="accident 5"/> The weight of 4876 caused it to fall through the floor and into the station's basement. A temporary floor was erected over the engine, and the hole it created, for the [[United States presidential inauguration|inauguration]] of [[President of the United States|President]] [[Dwight D. Eisenhower]].<ref name="Loftus 16"/> 4876 was eventually dismantled and removed from the basement. It was reassembled in Altoona, before being put back into service.
â   â
[[File:CrashedGG1.jpg|thumb|left|PRR 4876 after the crash in Union Station.|alt=A locomotive with its pantograph raised, lying at angle and partially tipped over, with wreckage strewn about it.]]
 
The accident was determined to have been caused by a "angle cock", a valve on the front and rear of a locomotive and rail cars used in the train's [[Railway air brake|airbraking]] system, on the rear of the third car in the train that had inadvertenly closed.<ref>"Accident at Union Station", p. 13.</ref> The handle of the angle cock had been improperly placed and had come into contact with the bottom of the car. Once it was closed, the brakes on all the cars behind the closed valve would not have been able to be applied.<ref>"Accident at Union Station, p. 14.</ref>
The accident was determined to have been caused by a "angle cock", a valve on the front and rear of a locomotive and rail cars used in the train's [[Railway air brake|airbraking]] system, on the rear of the third car in the train that had inadvertenly closed.<ref>"Accident at Union Station", p. 13.</ref> The handle of the angle cock had been improperly placed and had come into contact with the bottom of the car. Once it was closed, the brakes on all the cars behind the closed valve would not have been able to be applied.<ref>"Accident at Union Station, p. 14.</ref>
